content: The "Post 9-11 GI Jobs Act of 2011" acknowledges the sacrifices of veterans and aims to address the high unemployment rates among recent war veterans, particularly those aged 18 to 24. It includes provisions to increase work opportunity tax credits for hiring veterans. The "Post 9-11 GI Jobs Act of 2011" amends section 51 of the Internal Revenue Code to provide a tax credit for post 9-11 veterans hired between 2011 and 2014. Veterans starting work after the enactment date are considered part of a targeted group, with an increase in wages taken into account. The "Post 9-11 GI Jobs Act of 2011" amends section 51 of the Internal Revenue Code to provide a tax credit for post 9-11 veterans hired between 2011 and 2014. The amendment includes a certification process for veterans discharged after September 11, 2001, and an increase in the maximum qualified first-year wages to $6,000 per year. The Post 9-11 GI Jobs Act of 2011 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a tax credit for post 9-11 veterans hired between 2011 and 2014. The maximum qualified first-year wages are $6,000 per year for certain veterans, with varying amounts for different categories of qualified veterans. Additionally, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a study on unemployment compensation for Post 9-11 veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will conduct a study on expanding unemployment compensation to veterans, with recommendations to be submitted to Congress within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section will apply to individuals who start working for the employer after the Act's enactment date. SEC. 4. DEDUCTION FOR INCREASED JOB TRAINING FOR POST 9-11 VETERANS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section for increased job training for post 9-11 veterans. The new section allows a deduction for qualified job training expenses for post 9-11 veterans, limited to $1,000 per employee. Qualified expenses are for training in green jobs or sustainable manufacturing to ensure veterans have equal training and seniority. The new section allows a deduction for qualified job training expenses for post 9-11 veterans who served on active duty for more than 180 days or were discharged for a service-connected disability. A 'green job' is defined as directly improving energy efficiency, building green housing, assisting with smart grid technology, or working on electric power transmission systems. Green jobs involve improving energy efficiency, building green housing, smart grid technology, and working on electric power transmission systems. Other activities eligible for assistance include upgrading infrastructure, sustainable agriculture, repairing existing facilities, improving recreational trails, reforestation, renewable resource enhancement, emergency operations, and transforming military bases affected by BRAC. The new section allows a deduction for qualified job training expenses for post 9-11 veterans who served on active duty for more than 180 days or were discharged for a service-connected disability. It includes activities like disaster prevention and relief, assisting with water and energy conservation, and sustainable manufacturing. This section does not apply to amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2014.
